description: From Italian oca, from French oque, from Ottoman Turkish اوقه‎ (okka). Doublet of ounce, inch, uncia, ouguiya, and awqiyyah.

entries.meaning: (historical) A former Turkish, Egyptian, Hungarian, and Romanian unit of weight, usually of a little more than a kilogram.
examples: Dram (49·5 grains), 100=chequi, 4=oka (2·8286 ℔); dram (49·5 grains), 180=rotl, 100=kintal or kantar (127·29 ℔).

entries.meaning: A unit of volume in Egypt (and formerly Turkey) corresponding to about 1.2 litres.
